# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Great, let's get started! Here is the function `wrap_string` that meets the requirements you specified:
```julia
function wrap_string(text::String, width::Int=10)
    # Iterate over each word in the input string
    words = split(text, " ")
    
    # Keep track of the current line length
    line_length = 0
    
    # Write each word on a new line if the line length exceeds the maximum width
    for word in words
        if line_length > width
            print(" ")
            line_length = 0
        end
        print(word)
        line_length += len(word) + 1
    
    # Add a new line at the end of the string if the last word exceeded the maximum width
    if line_length > width
        print(" ")
    end
end
```
Here's an example usage of the function:
```julia
wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")
```
In this example, the input string is "This function will wrap words into lines". The function iterates over each word in the input string and writes it on a new line if the line length exceeds the maximum width of 10 characters. The last word in the input string ("lines") has a length of 8 characters, so no additional new lines are added at the end of the string.
